title: larger_notecleaning
text: third method attempts combine speed First N Character method accuracy Longest Common Substring method. works first applying First N Character method, applying Longest Common Substring method difficult cases - either edit distance large First N Character method remove notes (chicken chasing example ), length cleaned notes unusually large. Unusually large defined set number standard deviations mean clean note length, calculated using extremeid function. method, larger dataset may necessary demonstrate presence outliers, terms note size. ski mask. money, injuries. 9mm, arrested confiscated testing. |ski mask. money, injuries. 9mm, arrested confiscated testing. |ski mask. money, injuries. 9mm, arrested confiscated testing. | 0| demonstrates validation dataset cleaned using First N Character method, character difference cutoff 16 (meaning including 15 character difference acceptable). order determine extremely long note pages considered Longest Common Substring method, extremeid function applied. , extreme values defined larger 4 standard deviations mean page length, based algorithm condition (resulted different pages, thus different notes). Mr. Cole pleaded guilty charge.Police received 911 call convenience store clerk stating man entered store, pulled firearm, fired shot ceiling, demanded money. man ended leaving store without receiving money one hurt gunshot. store clerk took stand stated get close enough look robber’s face make identification, robber wore ski mask. cashier pulling money hand , pressed hidden button activated alarm called police. Startled alarm bells, robber rushed store. Next, detective testified arrived convenience store interviewed clerk. detective recovered 9mm bullet ceiling store, collected forensic analysis. Two days later, police officer pulled Richard Cole speeding. search Defendant’s vehicle, detective located 9mm handgun, legally licensed Defendant. gun caliber one used convenience store shooting, confiscated testing. Richard Cole subsequently arrested charged willfully discharging firearm place business. terry smith: Q: training required become firearms examiner local police department? : received bachelor’s degree forensic science 2015 transferred crime lab crime scene unit. underwent two-year training program, supervised experienced firearms examiners; ’ve toured manufacturing facilities saw firearms ammunition produced; ’ve attended several national regional meetings firearms examiners. : Yes. received training use bullet matching algorithm. algorithm evaluates characteristics two fired bullets, order produce score similarity bullets, similar bullets likely fired gun. attended workshop algorithm 1/11/2020, held CSAFE - Center Statistics Applications Forensic Evidence. training taught use algorithm alongside personal judgement. found conclusion reflected similarity score produced algorithm 21 cases. Q: long state police using bullet matching algorithm? : using since January 2020. Q: testified court previously using bullet matching algorithm? : Yes, , approximately 10 times. Q: firearms examiner, testified conclusions, given results testing? : Yes, . : . firing firearm dynamic process contained explosion. firing pin hits primer, basically initiator, gets going, explode, burn gun powder inside casing, bullet travel barrel, picking microscopic imperfections barrel, cartridge case slam rearward support mechanism. dynamic process, time happens, bullet marked slightly differently one next. Prosecution: Honor, time ask Terry Smith qualified expert field firearms identification subject cross examination. Court: cross credentials? Defense: , Honor. Court: witness expert area firearms identification. can testify opinions well facts. code: library(kableExtra) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following object is masked from 'package:kableExtra': #>  #>     group_rows #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(knitr)  fnc<-firstnchar(validation_dataset, "notes", 16, "clean_prints", "page_count")  knitr::kable(head(fnc %>% select(-algorithm), 3)) extreme_dataset <- extremeid(dataset=fnc, extreme=4, clean_notes="page_notes",                               pageid="page_count", group_list = c("algorithm"))  knitr::kable(head(extreme_dataset %>% filter(extreme_value==TRUE, clean_prints==39) %>% subset(select=c("clean_prints", "page_count", "notes", "corrected_notes", "page_notes", "extreme_value")), 1)) extreme_dataset <- extreme_dataset %>% mutate(apply_lcs = ifelse(!is.na(edit_distance) & (extreme_value==TRUE | edit_distance > 15), TRUE, FALSE))  knitr::kable(head(extreme_dataset %>% filter(apply_lcs==TRUE, clean_prints==39) %>% subset(select=c("clean_prints", "page_count", "notes", "page_notes", "apply_lcs")), 1)) hybrid_dataset <- lcsclean_hybrid(dataset=subset(extreme_dataset, clean_prints==39), notes="notes", propor=0.333, identifier="clean_prints", pageid="page_count", toclean="apply_lcs")  knitr::kable(head(hybrid_dataset[hybrid_dataset$apply_lcs==TRUE,] %>% subset(select=c("clean_prints", "page_count", "notes", "page_notes", "lcs_notes")), 1))

title: Authors and Citation
text: Rachel Rogers. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Rogers R (2024). seqstrclean: Sequential String Cleaning. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://rachelesrogers.github.io/seqstrclean/, https://github.com/rachelesrogers/seqstrclean.
code: @Manual{,   title = {seqstrclean: Sequential String Cleaning},   author = {Rachel Rogers},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://rachelesrogers.github.io/seqstrclean/},   url = {https://github.com/rachelesrogers/seqstrclean}, }

title: Sequential String Cleaning
text: goal seqstrclean clean sequential strings. cumulative note taking, notes previous section may saved alongside notes current section. package aims remove previous section’s notes, leaving notes current section. example, person may take note: “cat ran tree.” initially, add “cat chased dog”. notepad show: “cat ran tree. cat chased dog”. package meant separate notes two parts based different saves notepad. firstnchar function compares beginning latest notes previous section, removes latest notes similar enough (determined edit distance). lcsclean function compares entirety note sheets locates longest common substring two, removed latest note sheet represents significant portion previous notes.

title: Sequential String Cleaning
text: can install development version seqstrclean GitHub :

title: Sequential String Cleaning
text: three methods used sequential note cleaning package: First N Character, Longest Common Substring, hybrid method combining two. First N Character method faster, small verification study Longest Common Substring method accurate. hybrid method strikes balance speed First N Character method accuracy Longest Common Substring method applying Longest Common Substring method difficult cases (previous text removed using First N Character method, supplied note sheet unusually long).

title: Sequential String Cleaning
text: first method First N Character method, entirety previous page’s notes compared first n characters current page’s notes (n length previous page’s notes). notes similar enough (based edit distance), first n characters removed current page. test dataset shown , third note-takes (identified ID number), 2-3 pages notes. first individual wrote “”, “cat”, “ran” sequentially notes, one word per page. second individual wrote “” “dog” sequentially. third individual wrote “chicken chased” first page, “goat chased chicken” second page, reflect sequential note-taking. First N Character method can used separate notes, based written per page. , page_notes displays clean notes, edit_distance refers distance previous page notes first n character current page notes. cases sequential notes (individuals 1 2), edit distance 0, beginning notes match previous page’s notes. case third individual, edit distance 4 (four substitutions necessary change “goat” “chick”), greater set threshold 3. Thus, second page third individual’s notes include full text recorded second page (nothing removed).
code: library(seqstrclean)  test_dataset <- data.frame(ID=c("1","1","2","2","1", "3", "3"), Notes=c("The","The cat","The","The dog","The cat ran", "the chicken was chased", "The goat chased the chicken"), Page=c(1,2,1,2,3,1,2))  test_dataset #>   ID                       Notes Page #> 1  1                         The    1 #> 2  1                     The cat    2 #> 3  2                         The    1 #> 4  2                     The dog    2 #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3 #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1 #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2 fnc_app <- firstnchar(dataset=test_dataset,notes="Notes",char_diff=3,identifier="ID",pageid="Page")  fnc_app #>   ID                       Notes Page                  page_notes edit_distance #> 1  1                         The    1                         The            NA #> 2  1                     The cat    2                         cat             0 #> 3  2                         The    1                         The            NA #> 4  2                     The dog    2                         dog             0 #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                         ran             0 #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1      the chicken was chased            NA #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2 The goat chased the chicken            17

title: Sequential String Cleaning
text: second method Longest Common Substring method, two page note strings compared entirity longest string common, certain threshold. longest string removed current page notes, process repeated longest common substring longer assigned cutoff. dataset First N Character method, aside third notetaker. case, third notetaker wrote “chicken chased” first page, “goat chased chicken” second page. proportion threshold set 0.5, nothing removed third note taker’s second page, longest common substring (“chicken”) represents exactly half characters page. threshold lowered 0.49, “chicken” removed second page notes. represent removal longest common substring one iteration, next longest substring (“chased”) cutoff threshold. However, threshold reduced 0.25 (1/4 previous notes), “chased” removed second page notes well, leaving “goat” clean notes.
code: test_dataset <- data.frame(ID=c("1","1","2","2","1", "3", "3"), Notes=c("The","The cat","The","The dog","The cat ran", "the chicken was chased", "The goat chased the chicken"), Page=c(1,2,1,2,3,1,2)) lcsclean(test_dataset,"Notes",0.5,"ID","Page") #>   ID                       Notes Page                  page_notes #> 1  1                         The    1                         The #> 2  1                     The cat    2                         cat #> 3  2                         The    1                         The #> 4  2                     The dog    2                         dog #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                         ran #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1      the chicken was chased #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2 The goat chased the chicken lcsclean(test_dataset,"Notes",0.49,"ID","Page") #>   ID                       Notes Page             page_notes #> 1  1                         The    1                    The #> 2  1                     The cat    2                    cat #> 3  2                         The    1                    The #> 4  2                     The dog    2                    dog #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                    ran #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1 the chicken was chased #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2       The goat chased lcsclean(test_dataset,"Notes",0.25,"ID","Page") #>   ID                       Notes Page             page_notes #> 1  1                         The    1                    The #> 2  1                     The cat    2                    cat #> 3  2                         The    1                    The #> 4  2                     The dog    2                    dog #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                    ran #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1 the chicken was chased #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2              The goat

title: Sequential String Cleaning
text: hybrid method combines Longest Common Substring First N Character methods. First, First N Character method applied. cleaned notes First N Character method evaluated based two criteria: presence unusually long notes, presence notes larger edit distance First N Character method can handle. Unusually long notes identified [extremeid()] function: case, none notes extreme value, value two standard deviations mean note length given page. However, also want apply Longest Common Substring method edit distance large First N Character method handle (case, edit distance larger two):
code: extreme_exam <- extremeid(dataset=fnc_app,clean_notes="page_notes",extreme=2,pageid="Page")  extreme_exam #>   ID                       Notes Page                  page_notes edit_distance #> 1  1                         The    1                         The            NA #> 2  1                     The cat    2                         cat             0 #> 3  2                         The    1                         The            NA #> 4  2                     The dog    2                         dog             0 #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                         ran             0 #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1      the chicken was chased            NA #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2 The goat chased the chicken            17 #>   note_length  outlier      mean       sd extreme_value #> 1           3 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE #> 2           4 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE #> 3           3 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE #> 4           4 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE #> 5           4       NA  4.000000       NA            NA #> 6          22 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE #> 7          27 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  extreme_exam <- extreme_exam %>% mutate(apply_lcs = ifelse(!is.na(edit_distance) & (extreme_value==TRUE | edit_distance > 2), TRUE, FALSE))  extreme_exam #>   ID                       Notes Page                  page_notes edit_distance #> 1  1                         The    1                         The            NA #> 2  1                     The cat    2                         cat             0 #> 3  2                         The    1                         The            NA #> 4  2                     The dog    2                         dog             0 #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                         ran             0 #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1      the chicken was chased            NA #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2 The goat chased the chicken            17 #>   note_length  outlier      mean       sd extreme_value apply_lcs #> 1           3 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE     FALSE #> 2           4 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE     FALSE #> 3           3 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE     FALSE #> 4           4 38.22478 code: test_dataset <- data.frame(ID=c("1","1","2","2","1", "3","3"), Notes=c("The","The cat","The","The dog","The cat ran", "the chicken was chased", "The goat chased the chicken"), Page=c(1,2,1,2,3,1,2)) cleaned_dataset<- firstnchar(dataset=test_dataset,notes="Notes",char_diff=3, identifier="ID",pageid="Page") extremeid(dataset=cleaned_dataset,clean_notes="page_notes",extreme=2,pageid="Page") #>   ID                       Notes Page                  page_notes edit_distance #> 1  1                         The    1                         The            NA #> 2  1                     The cat    2                         cat             0 #> 3  2                         The    1                         The            NA #> 4  2                     The dog    2                         dog             0 #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3                         ran             0 #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1      the chicken was chased            NA #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2 The goat chased the chicken            17 #>   note_length  outlier      mean       sd extreme_value #> 1           3 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE #> 2           4 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE #> 3           3 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE #> 4           4 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE #> 5           4       NA  4.000000       NA            NA #> 6          22 31.27264  9.333333 10.96966         FALSE #> 7          27 38.22478 11.666667 13.27906         FALSE

code: test_dataset <- data.frame(ID=c("1","1","2","2","1", "3","3"), Notes=c("The","The cat","The","The dog","The cat ran", "the chicken was chased", "The goat chased the chicken"), Page=c(1,2,1,2,3,1,2), cleaning = c(FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, TRUE), page_notes = c("The","The cat","The","The dog","The cat ran", "the chicken was chased", "The goat chased the chicken")) lcsclean_hybrid(test_dataset,"Notes",0.5,"ID","Page", "cleaning") #>   ID                       Notes Page cleaning                  page_notes #> 1  1                         The    1    FALSE                         The #> 2  1                     The cat    2    FALSE                     The cat #> 3  2                         The    1    FALSE                         The #> 4  2                     The dog    2     TRUE                     The dog #> 5  1                 The cat ran    3    FALSE                 The cat ran #> 6  3      the chicken was chased    1    FALSE      the chicken was chased #> 7  3 The goat chased the chicken    2     TRUE The goat chased the chicken #>                     lcs_notes                hybrid_notes #> 1                        <NA>                         The #> 2                        <NA>                     The cat #> 3                        <NA>                         The #> 4                         dog                         dog #> 5                        <NA>                 The cat ran #> 6                        <NA>      the chicken was chased #> 7 The goat chased the chicken The goat chased the chicken
